So... you finished the game? Time to bust out some of what you've learned from just finishing the game and make your own level! Not very many games I know has this kind of feature that's something I would think only the developers would have and not share to people. Highly recommended and worth the money.Try it out! 												Brilliant!I'm having a blast playing Camera Obscura. The unique art style is great and really gives me a fun and retro-indie feel, but with a professional polish. Combined with such an amazing sound track that's worth a purchase all on its own, this game experience has been exactly what I was hoping for. Each time I overcome an interesting hurdle in Camera Obscura I'm always left with both a rewarding feeling and the curious notion of whether or not that was the only solution to the puzzle. The snapshot "afterimage" mechanic is so clever in the unbelievable number of unforseen ways it can be used and in how easily it adapts to the user's play style. I found myself constantly discovering new ways to solve simple and complex puzzles, even surprising myself with solutions I hadn't seen at first.The controls feel very smooth and play wonderfully with a game pad. 												Since the game's release I've put about eight hours into it, about split evenly between level progression and trying to get the various medals. It's proven to be a very addicting game, as I'm finding myself saying 'okay one more try' or 'let me see what this next level is' many times. It's also very fun, there's not much to it apart from the various platforming elements. There's still some stuff in the trailer I haven't gotten to yet, so the game doesn't throw everything at you right away, and each level is pretty different. The platforming is nice and tight, as you're able to control how hard you jump, which comes in handy during speedruns when you just need to make a little hop. Respawns are quick, or if you want to restart the level, that's very fast as well. The camera element, or 'flashing', is interesting. Essentially, when you hit X, you make an afterimage of the background, which follows you for about two seconds before stopping, and then stays there for a few seconds more. You use this to create steps, lift enemies, and get to places you otherwise couldn't reach. It will take a bit of time to master this, as you'll have to learn when is the best time to jump before the platform halts its movement. But when you do you'll be able to move around levels like a pro.Each level has a Time challenge and a Flash challenge. Bronze, Silver, and Gold medals for using the least amount of flashes possible, or beating it in the least amount of time. Sometimes getting gold for both happens at the same time, sometimes they're mutually exclusive. They're definitely challenging, but I wouldn't say they're unfair. Though it can be aggravating getting a time of 23.01 and you need to get a 23.00 to get the gold. But it's fun to see what shortcuts are in the levels. One that comes to mind can be completed in about five seconds, or over a minute, depending on if you know the trick or not. And when you're doing the speedruns, you'll often find the enemies are placed in juuust the right area to screw you over if you don't do it right. But then you get to do it and then you can laugh and laugh and laugh.For the story, I haven't really delved into it yet. There are mementos you can find as collectibles. The main character is a photographer, and she's looking for somebody at the top of this tower. But anything other than that I either don't know or don't want to spoil. The memento give a history of the tower you're climbing, and what you're trying to accomplish, but it's not needed to enjoy the game. Only problem I have with this is there's no indication of what levels have mementos left uncollected, so you may want to write down what mementos you find in each level, as they're at least numbered.The music is nice, I think there are about eleven tracks. They don't get repetitive and create a nice ambience for the game. Tempted to pick up the soundtrack myself. I would estimate that if you were just going through the game, trying to get to the end, it would last you at least ten hours? I'm only at the halfway point myself, and it's definitely getting harder, so it'll take longer to beat the last levels. But it still hasn't reached unfair levels of difficulty, or Braid-level lateral reasoning to beat a puzzle. But then, that time doesn't count trying to get medals, or going back for mementos you missed. I did end up spending half an hour trying to get the two golds on one tricky level, but that feeling of satisfaction after I got them, oh, that was palpable.There's also a level creator, but I haven't yet gone into that. But that's definitely something I'm looking forward to seeing after everyone develops some new levels. For the levels in the game, as I said before, there's a lot of variety. It changes the general theme of the level as you climb the tower, getting more mechanical as opposed to the stony architecture of the first levels, which is cool. There are moving platforms, switches you need to hit (or use monsters to hit), tiles that can't be flashed, tiles that need to be switched on to be flashed, and oh yes: no spikes whatsoever. If you die it's simply from falling down a pit or touching an enemy.Definitely a good purchase, especially for the price. Absolutely recommended.

												There's no doubt that retro-style games are making a comeback. Casual gamers like the simplicity, core gamers love the novelty, and both groups appreciate the low price. Camera Obscura is a side-scrolling puzzle/platformer from Anteater Games that could have easily been made in the '90s, but it still provides an interesting challenge that will appeal to modern gamers.Camera obscura, which is Latin for “dark chamber," is both an accurate description of early box cameras and also a metaphor for the gloomy tower in which the game takes place. As the story begins, you take control of an unnamed protagonist armed only with a magical camera that can manipulate the environment. The protagonist enters a giant, mysterious tower that stretches far into the sky and proceeds to ascend to the top. It's unknown why the tower exists and why it was abandoned, but you can uncover the secrets by finding pictures scattered throughout the environment.At its core, Camera Obscura is a very challenging platformer that requires pixel-perfect precision in both movement and jumps. Since the protagonist moves at a jogging pace, it's easy to fall off small platforms to your doom or mistime jumps. Fortunately, there's an endless supply of lives, and you usually respawn close to where you died. Additional challenge is provided by enemies like deadly slime creatures and flying bats that instantly kill players when they're touched. When you add the Afterimage mechanic to the mix, the resulting difficulty may have you cursing your screen so much that neighbors will wonder if you have Tourette Syndrome.One button press is all it takes to initiate the innovative Afterimage flash effect that clones the environment for a few seconds. When this occurs, the player can move to the side or jump up or down to move the Afterimage in the same direction. This process can create bridges to run on or steps to climb, freeze moving platforms, and even trap or crush enemies. It seems like a simple concept, but the Afterimage can be used in a wide variety of ways that depend on your imagination. Since the effect only lasts for a few seconds, the chance of making a mistake is greatly amplified, especially when trying to rush through a level.Speaking of which, this game has 57 maps that take place both inside and outside of the tower. Players can earn one bronze, silver, or gold medal for each map depending on the time it takes to finish a map and one medal for how many afterimage flashes they used. Replaying maps to earn gold medals helps to extend the game's length for perfectionists and anyone who desires a difficult challenge. In addition, any player can utilize the user-friendly level editor to create and upload maps to further extend the replay value. Although the retro visuals are pixelated, they still look very cool. The blocky aesthetic of the main environments remind me of Dig Dug, but with more stylish and detailed backgrounds. I also appreciate the beautiful soundtrack that puts me in a mellow mood with its cathartic melodies. It's just too bad that, just like exploring any dark room, a few bugs tarnish the experience. My biggest gripe is how customized controls reset to their default setup every time the game is launched. Other launch problems include low framerates and random crashes.Camera Obscura is definitely a niche game with simplistic gameplay, but it has a certain charm that will captivate anyone who gives it a try.

												Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Camera Obscura with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.     I’m relatively predictable when it comes to my opinion of puzzle platformers; I don’t think they’re fun. Off the top of my head only two exceptions come to mind, the first being the Trine games, and the second being Thomas Was Alone. The key feature with both of those is that they’re more heavily story driven than their peers. Camera Obscura certainly did nothing to change my opinion of puzzle platforming, I didn’t have fun with the hour or so I spent with it, but I have to recommend it anyway.     The key mechanic is the ability to trigger a camera flash which creates an afterimage of the current visible terrain which you can then move around with your character. It’s difficult to explain on paper but the effect is really interesting. I have seen some games which allow for a certain segments of the screen to be captured and moved about but trying to work with all the visible terrain opens up many more possibilities as well as previously unconsidered challenges.I didn’t find it fun but I think it’s a well made platformer with an intriguing mechanic worthy of some attention.

												Camera Obscura is a "puzzle" platformer, although the biggest gripe I have is that some of the "puzzles" don't feel very fair in their design, and where a simple mistake in later levels can force you to restart the whole level, like racing a slime to the end of the level, only to accidently kill it with your camera. How do you kill a slime with a camera, you ask? Simple: Using your camera (which, beyond jumping, is all you can do), you take a shadowy copy of the immediate surrounding landscape that is centered around you, and it follows you for a moment before freezing in place, which when combined with jumping and falling, can allow you to reach new heights, cross large chasms, or crush enemies between the shadowy terrain and the real terrain.While you are able to prematurely dismiss the shadowy terrain you make with your camera, you have no way to deal with the few creatures in the game if encountered in large, open areas, to which most of the levels are designed as, and several levels throw sharp spikes in difficulty at you, like trying to jump from a higher, wider ledge down to a lower, more narrow ledge that is under the wider one, or like in the example in the first paragraph, racing a slime without killing it or letting it get too far ahead of you. There are three other incentives that will also demand perfection from you with the use of your camera; Photos, Flash medals, and Time trial medals.Photos are the game's collectable and actually don't have any images on them, but rather they give details of the game's world and the protagonist's backstory, yet some of them require tricky or advanced shadowy terrain manipulation to reach. Flash medals are rewarded based on how many times you used the camera to make shadowy terrain; the fewer used, the better the medal. Time Trial medals are, well, rewarded on how fast you finish a level. Very straight forward for those. Between the three, they are ment to create replay value for the game, however the absurd increase in difficulty without proper tutorials creates frustration, especially when ingame text about your controls is spread few and far apart (which should be covered in like, say, a tutorial).All in all, if you plan to pick up the game for yourself, pick it up only when it's on sale; The frustration induced by this "puzzle" platformer is not welcomed.

												Camera Obscura is a cute little indie game that I admittedly had not had high expectations for.  Whenever you get a game for a quarter, you can't ever be sure of the quality. But I will say I was pleasantly surprised. CO is a puzzle platformer that plays in the vein of games like Braid. It's only controls are jumping, movement, peeking your field of view ahead, and it's key mechanic: the ability to take pictures of the landscape, and as it "develops", it creates additional platforms to jump across. The soundtrack is soothing, the graphics are cutesy, if a bit uninspiring, and the story plays out in collectible pickups. The ambiguity of what's happening at first again strikes of Braid. For this innovative mechanic alone, the game accomplishes a very tight level of game design. The difficulty curve is structured around gradually inputing more challenges that stretch your ability to use the mechanic in new and creative ways. A good puzzle platformer like Camera Obscura has very simple mechanics that extrapolate in complexity as the game goes on.The game is not without its faults, however. The difficulty in the last few levels ramps up considerably, and the final level is excruitaitingly frustrating because of checkpoint drought. There are a few puzzles where you have to guide little mobs to hit switches for you, and it's possible for them to die and not respawn, so the puzzle becomes unsolvable until you die, at which point, you revert to the last checkpoint, and possibly, the beginning of the level. Another point of frustration is moving or timed levels, where you have to snap a pic at just the right time; a millisecond too slow or fast means starting the level over again.All in all though, Camera Obscura is a solid game with a good bit of replay value. The level design is solid and the expanding complexity of the one simple mechanic is textbook game design. Camera Obscura is no gaming titan, but it is worth your time.

Posted: December 27, 2015
												A simple game with a simple idea and a fairly simple execution. As per required in the independent landscape, this particular "platformer with a twist" lets you create temporary platforms that move with you when you use your camera, hence the title. It's not a bad gimmick in the slightest, but one that I never felt was fully realized during my playthrough. While some of the level layouts were fairly interesting, the only times I ever found myself stuck was when I overthought a problem. Sometimes that can be effective, but there is a difference between intellegent misdirection and mediocre level design. To be fair, there are a few sections that did have a couple of "aha!" moments, but even though the platforming was inoffensive most times, I can't emphasize enough the missed potential here. CO shines at its brightest when the levels themselves are puzzles, and its a shame to see that the majority of the game consists mostly of cheap filler. With more control over the afterimage effects, or maybe some sort of metroidvania skill ups for the camera to add new abilities within the fiction, I feel that while the game offered here is decent enough, there is little to engage the player all the way to the end. That is the real tragedy. So why the Yes? Two simple reasons; for all my criticisms, this is still a damn fine game. While I'd be strained to compare it to Braid or games of that nature, CO still pulses with charm that echoes ambition I haven't seen a fairly long time on this storefront. The platforming is a little stiff, but for the cheap price I keep seeing it for, I think it's a great little gem to kill some time with. The second reason is a bit more pretentious of me; Camera Obscura screams of potential, and I would love to see where this concept and its creator go from here. We all have to start somewhere, and as Anteater's first game on Steam I can't help but appreciate an inspired idea, flawed as it may be. For less than a gumball from a gumball machine, I think this game is absolutely worth giving a look. The lovely ambient soundtrack is worth the admission price alone. Definitely worth grabbing when on sale.

												I can't, in all good consciousness, recommend Camera Obscura. The tl;dr is below.-Repetitive gameplay-Repetitive music-Stiff art-Uninspired gameplay conceptFor a long time I've joked that to love indie games you must love 2D puzzle platformers. I have nothing wrong with the genre in theory, but there's been both a glut of puzzle platformers and little to distinguish them.The only thing that seems to set any of these games apart is their core concept, which is some supposedly inspired means of getting a new grip on the environment around you, like learning to think with Portals or the time you realized how the door puzzles worked in Braid.I have too many of these games who set their core puzzle premise so front and center that it's the only thing the game can be judged by. To name a few:-Closure-Out There Somewhere-FEZ-NightSky-Offspring Fling!-Snapshot-TrineBut frankly, there could be a million more but their quantity isn't the problem. It's that puzzles are a strange thing to stick to when testing new game mechanics and have to rely on both the cleverness of the puzzle itself and whether it's fun to solve.There are ways to make a game lean on more than just those qualities. Great art, engaging storyline, rich music, but too many indie games figure out something unique (though Camera Obscura isn't necessarily unique) and decide that its uniqueness is the quality by which it chooses to be judged.Camera Obscura has floaty, annoying controls, dull music, amateur art and story in the form of cryptic, over-wrought messages, so it was pretty boring overall.I don't mean to be mean, but I genuinely wish that indie developers would choose to be unique with more than just their puzzle mechanics and Camera Obscura doesn't even really do that very well.

												Camera Obscura is an earnest, well-conceived, enjoyable game that feels like it was the first effort of a new developer (which it was). The game is a puzzle-platformer whose signature mechanic is the ability to create temporary platforms using a camera. Once they are there, the player can move for a bit before they solidify, and then jump on them before they disappear. Platformers with special mechanics tend to walk a fine line-either the mechanic makes the game too easy, or the developer overcorrects and it becomes too hard. Camera Obscura leans on the "hard" end of that line but doesn't cross it, and I say this as someone who, as of the time of this review, was encountering a substantial ramp-up in difficulty. I do have to repeat that the game is indeed difficult. Probably to ensure the use of the flash-platforms, the main character cannot jump very high on her own, and many stages require careful environmental management to progress (both the stage I'm currently up to and the one I just completed require you to keep a fragile enemy alive to solve a puzzle). The game just has a good "feeling" to it, the feeling of puzzle completion, the excellent soundtrack (which in my opinion is reason enough to buy the game by itself), and the sense of being seemingly stuck but knowing there just has to be a way out (which is what the difficulty entails).However, the game also has some of the weaknesses one would expect from new developers. The flash-platform mechanic is imperfect and works a lot better in horizontal movement than in vertical ones, and making the right platform is often not a matter of ingenious puzzle-solving, but pure trial-and-error. The soundtrack and setting of the game imply a slower, contemplative atmosphere, but the frequent need for fast reflexes often contradicts it. Also, though not the fault of the developers themselves, the obscurity (no pun intended) of the game means there's little outside documentation. This, combined with the difficulty, means that a player may be forced to ask around should they be stuck (as I was)The relative weakness of the main character without the camera and the fact that she slides a little too much can be a little annoying. Finally, without spoiling anything, the game has more of a plot than it actually needs, and said plot isn't the best-written (although it's a very small part of the game).In spite of these, Camera Obscura is a worthy puzzle-platformer. None of the flaws are insurmountable, and none make the game feel tiresome to play, as opposed to just difficult. I got it for sale at a very low price, but it's definitely worth buying at its regular one. While one may be annoyed at how the door to the next level is so close but so far, and struggle with making just the right platform, once they reach the door, the feeling of satisfaction is all the sweeter.

It's awesome we need more of it, but she's constantly staring at me, its kind of unnerving and a little frightening.  Why? Why are you looking at mt?  Look where your going, just look where you're going!  You're animating your sprite, which is awesome, just turn her head, just turn her head. She's always looking at you, judging you! "Why did you jump then? Why didn't you jump before? Huh? Oh, so that's how you're playing.  I'll remember that."Camera Obscura's camera mechanic, what do you call this mechanic? I don't know but I love it.  I love the idea of it and everything that can be done with it.  It just needs a better game to better realize its potential, I see great things for this.  Remember Narbacular Drop?  It was an okay game, not a great game but a okay game with a great mechanic in need of a great game, Portal became its great game.  Camera Obscura is like that game, it has a great mechanic in need of a great game.Camera Obscura, its a fun title.  The music was, a little repetitive, really repetitive, like super repetitive. It felt like a ten second clip looped ad infinitum.  It was... the music needed a lot of work, I'm not gonna lie.Verdict?  Well if you want a challenge give it a go.  I may never touch it again, but then I really love the camera capture, so maybe I will.  I haven't a clue.Go live you're own life and stop listening to me!

												In Camera Obscura you play a photographer scaling a decaying tower. Your camera has the strange ability to create after images of various platforms. These after images start off being able to slowly move based off your own movements but will eventually freeze up.Once you learn to use the After Images this game becomes a lot easier and has a lot more variety in its puzzle solving.Some of the puzzles are a little bit too frustrating. The game will sometimes task you with getting an enemy to a button to flip a door open, this enemy can easily be killed if you're not careful. These missions are some of the most frustrating missions ever. The game is hard and sometimes unfair, however it is mostly enjoyable except for one thing, the level 8-2. This level is just awful, it's unclear what they want you to do and the flow is just horrible. The fact that every guide I found online was about ways to skip half of the level, should show you how hated it is. If you make it that far I suggest you learn how to skip it as well, it's not worth the effort doing it the way the designers wanted it done.Thankfully the last level is fairly easy but has beautiful back grounds and a great musical score. It really does feel like the climax to your journey and is a great last level.On the artistic side I found the back grounds to be pretty good. Some of them even are breath taking. While the sprite work is just average. The monsters don't seem to fit with the main characters art design, instead looking like your standard run of the mill monsters. It's a shame they couldn't come up with something more intresting than, slime, bat, bug. Though the ant eater is a bit different ( though they are Anteater games ). However the true failure in this game, is the sprite animation. Slimes mysteriously grow butts, the main character jumps by just clapping her feet together. Your death animation is a silly double spin. The games animation is just a bit janky, nothing that upsets me, it just makes the game feel a bit cheap. ( Though the death animation IS hilarious ). However it does have artistic flourishes like having several idle animations that are pretty good, and even animating the scarf when she falls.The story is given to you in bits and pieces, scattered across the levels in collectable polaroids. I collected them where I could and got above 75% of them, however I wish they didn't just use the polaroids. For example in Thomas was Alone, they had a voice over that gave you bits of the story and characterization. I would have liked something similar, maybe just text appearing as you played the level. In the last level they have dialouge, but when you get to the end all you get is a samll image in the end credits. All in all I think this game isn't the best game, but it has intresting mechanics and some fun levels with a story that is a bit charming. So for the price tag I say it's worth it to play, at least up till 8-2. TLDR: It's 1.99 you get what you pay for. It's enjoyable for the most part but some levels will have you tearing out your hair.

												So, one day someone says 'I want to make a videogame'. They put on their thinking cap, gather their resources, and tediously come up with a plan-of-attack. Everyone is sitting around the boardroom, spit-balling ideas, and someone says:'Hey I got it - lets make one-trick-pony platformer with PS1 graphics! We will use the exact same mechanic as in Snapshot and essentially only use two buttons with looping ambient music. The art will be generic and so will all of the textures.'Who's in?---Ok, lets be serious though - its not terrible, and the puzzle gimmick is not half-bad either, but it is not something I would tell a friend to spend five bucks on, period. It is more like a proof-of-concept with placeholder art and music, at this point.  If I had to guess, this was made with some easy access video game making software, and very few of the resources are custom for this game. I see people on the forums enjoy speedrunning this, and I guess I get that. I love video games, and I love to play lots of them, but everybody is limited by time - why play sub-standard titles? I don't mean this as an insult, but it has to be said.I was gifted this game from a Steam account that regularly sends me titles to review. 												I'm a fan of puzzle-platforming games and CamObs was recommended to me in a said genre bundle pack. Bought it and started playing it. I have mixed feelings about this game, because while it feels kind of a puzzle to figure out how to navigate through the level, it is more of just a platforming game. The game itself isn't that much of a puzzle as you just navigate the character around. If you are inclined to collect the story bits via the polaroids, then it might be slightly more of a puzzle to reach said story bits as some levels have them tucked away at niches that you might miss or don't know how to reach. Looking at the guides, it looks some a few are really hard to get and one that no one knows how to reach at this point.  To which, this leads to the game mechanic. It is interesting as you take images to extend your platform so you may reach farther than what the game is orginally designed. This is the entire basis of the game and while it is a bit dull, it is amusing to fiddle around and play with it during the game. This part of the game mechanic is to be applaud, but the camera pan mechanic to look further isn't as amazing. I'm using the steam controller and when I scroll to look ahead, it just scrolls back almost immediately. Maybe I need to configure the controller a bit more, but the scrolling ahead doesn't appear to be of much use except for to find out if jumping to that ledge yields a path or not. Then again, you can always just try jumping up there to see if there is anything without panning the camera that way. Probably, there will be a game level where mechanically, you need to simultaneously pan the camera and snap an image to extend your platform to reach the end of the level. (oh boy).Overall, the game can be fun if you enjoy platforming and learning about the storyline bit-by-bit. I would have liked more instructions on how to play the game before the game begins. That and clearer understanding of how the camera flash works instead of just trial and error to get a feel for it to understand it. Still, I'll play it in the long-term until I get bored of it.. 6/10.

												     This is a Braid-esque platformer in that it relies around a novel mechanic and pretension to artistic statement. The story is hinted at and implied through collectible photo icons that contain snippets of text. Some are descriptions of a religious cult and some are mopey rememberences of a lost love. None are very captivating.     The gameplay is really good, though. The player can use a camera to clone certain parts of the scenery to create new platforms and solve jumping puzzles. That sounds strange, but it's a very intuitive and original mechanic. The difficulty scales gradually over the course of a robust 50 or 60 levels and many of the later ones especially are challenging and well-designed.     This is not a very polished game. The graphics are remarkably bad, although they are strikingly similar to some of the worst graphics from the 1990's -- a decade this game pays clear homage to. Is this some high-concept intentional design choice? If it is, it's too subtle for a philistine like me. All I can say is that many of the assests look like they were created at the wrong resolution and then stretched to the proper size at the last minute. Also there is a common "bat" enemy that looks like it was drawn by a child. The music, on the other hand, is amusingly relaxing considering it is often the soundtrack to you dying over and over and over agin.     Quibbles aside, Camera Obscura is a fun, creative platformer that kept me engaged for 10 or 15 hours. It was a great deal for the 50 cents or whatever I paid for it. Recommended for sure.
